Knight argues the commission erred by not allowing Knight to get an indepedent medical examination of Risinger after a final order of the commission had been issued and Knight was paying benefits to Risinger under the final order.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Billy Risinger, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Knight Textiles, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Saluda County
Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3574
Submitted November 4, 2002 â€“ Filed December 
  9, 2002

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Darryl D. Smalls, of Columbia, for appellant.
S. Kirkpatrick Morgan, Jr. of Lexington, for respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Knight Textiles appeals an 
  order of the circuit court requiring it to provide certain medical treatment 
  recommended by Billy Risingerâ€™s physician for work-related injuries.Â  Knight 
  argues the commission erred in finding that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-80 does not 
  allow an employer to request an independent medical examination of an injured 
  employee when a final order of the commission has been issued and the employer 
  is paying benefits pursuant to the final order.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Risinger sustained a severe injury to his lower 
  back and spine when he slipped and fell off a dock area and landed on a metal 
  ramp while working for Knight.Â  Risinger was referred to Dr. Talley Parrott, 
  an orthopedic surgeon, in January 1998 for treatment.Â  Dr. Parrott recommended 
  surgical intervention for Risingerâ€™s right radicular pain and right disc herniation.Â  
  Knight, however, requested a second opinion from a neurosurgeon, Dr. Franklin 
  Epstein.Â  Dr. Epstein opined that Risingerâ€™s pain was â€œincapacitatingâ€ and recommended 
  a disc excision â€œin association with an interbody fusion.â€Â  Dr. Epstein performed 
  surgery in April 1998.Â  
In August 1999, the single commissioner determined that Risinger 
  was totally and permanently disabled.Â  The commissionerâ€™s order required that 
  Knight be â€œfinancially responsible for . . . lifetime medical benefits for [Risingerâ€™s] 
  compensable injury components per South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60.â€Â  At 
  the time the order was issued, Dr. Epstein was Risingerâ€™s authorized treating 
  physician.Â  Subsequent to the order, Dr. Epstein prescribed certain medications 
  and referred Risinger to Dr. David Steiner for chronic pain and depression.Â  
  Knight, however, refused to provide the medical treatment as recommended by 
  Dr. Epstein and Dr. Steiner.Â  
In February 2000, Risinger filed a Form 50 requesting payment 
  for the additional medical treatment.Â  Knight filed a Form 51 denying the additional 
  treatment and requesting an independent medical evaluation.Â  The single commissioner 
  found Knight was financially responsible for the medical treatment recommended 
  by Dr. Epstein and Dr. Steiner.Â  The commissioner also found S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 42-15-80 inapplicable when a final order of the commission has been issued 
  and the carrier is paying benefits pursuant to that order.Â  The full commission 
  affirmed the single commissioner.Â  Knight then appealed to the circuit court, 
  which affirmed the full commission.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œJudicial review of a Workersâ€™ Compensation decision 
  is governed by the substantial evidence rule of the Administrative Procedures 
  Act.â€Â  Lake v. Reeder Constr. Co., 330 S.C. 242, 246, 498 S.E.2d 650, 
  653 (Ct. App. 1998) (citing Wilson v. Georgetown County, 316 S.C. 92, 
  447 S.E.2d 841 (1994)).Â  â€œWe may not substitute our judgment for that of the 
  commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse 
  if the decision is affected by an error of law.â€Â  Brown v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 
  341 S.C. 611, 614, 535 S.E.2d 445, 447 (Ct. App. 2000) (cert. granted 
  May 23, 2001)(citation omitted).Â  â€œWe may reverse or modify a decision if the 
  findings and conclusions of the agency are affected by error of law, clearly 
  erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the 
  whole record, or arbitrary or capricious or characterized by abuse of discretion 
  or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.â€Â  Id. (citation omitted).
DISCUSSION
Knight first contends the circuit court erred in 
  finding that it was not entitled to an independent medical evaluation of Risinger.Â  
  Specifically, Knight argues that the circuit court and the workersâ€™ compensation 
  commission erred in finding that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-80 
  [2]  does not provide for an independent medical evaluation when a final 
  order has been issued and the employer/carrier is paying benefits pursuant to 
  a final order of the commission.Â  We disagree.
In this case, the workersâ€™ compensation commission 
  affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s finding that section 42-15-80 does not apply 
  when a final order has been issued and the carrier is paying benefitsÂ  pursuant 
  to a final order.Â  In this state, â€œ[t]he construction of a statute by the agency 
  charged with its administration should be accorded great deference and will 
  not be overruled without a compelling reason.â€Â  Vulcan Materials Co. v. Greenville 
  County Bd. of Zoning Appeals, 342 S.C. 480, 496, 536 S.E.2d 892, 900 (Ct. 
  App. 2000) (citations omitted).Â  We do not find that this case presents a compelling 
  reason to ignore the commissionâ€™s interpretation of the statute.Â  Moreover, 
  Knight chose Dr. Epstein to provide a second opinion concerning Risingerâ€™s condition. 
  Knight now refuses to pay for Dr. Epsteinâ€™s treatment and referral treatment 
  arguing it is entitled to yet another â€œsecondâ€ opinion.Â Â  Because we believe 
  Knight has already received the very relief it seeks, i.e., a second 
  opinion regarding Risingerâ€™s treatment, we find no merit to the argument that 
  it is entitled to what would effectively be a third opinion.
Finally, we believe Knightâ€™s interpretation of section 42-15-80 
  would lead to an absurd result.Â  See Broadhurst v. City of Myrtle 
  Beach Election Commâ€™n, 342 S.C. 373, 380, 537 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œ[H]owever 
  plain the ordinary meaning of the words used in a statute may be, the courts 
  will reject that meaning when to accept it would lead to a result so plainly 
  absurd that it could not possibly have been intended by the Legislature or would 
  defeat the plain legislative intention.â€) (citation omitted).Â  Under Knightâ€™s 
  interpretation of the statute, the employer/carrier would be able to continue 
  to seek a new doctorâ€™s opinion each time it did not like the opinion of the 
  claimantâ€™s doctor.Â  This would allow the employer/carrier to â€œshop aroundâ€ indefinitely 
  until it found a favorable opinion, often sacrificing much needed treatment.Â  
  We do not believe this result was intended by the legislature.Â  See id.Â  

Knight also argues the circuit court erred in finding 
  it was no longer entitled to control Risingerâ€™s medical treatment pursuant to 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 (1985).Â  We disagree.
Knight argues that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 obligates 
  Risinger to accept treatment from a treating physician of its choice.Â  Section 
  42-15-60 states in part:

In cases in which total and permanent disability results, 
  reasonable and necessary nursing services, medicines, prosthetic devices, sick 
  travel, medical, hospital and other treatment or care shall be paid during the 
  life of the injured employee, without regard to any limitation in this title 
  including the maximum compensation limit.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 (1985).
Initially, we note that Dr. 
  Epsteinâ€™s first examination of Risinger was an independent evaluation performed 
  at Knightâ€™s request.Â  Because Risinger is receiving treatment from the physician 
  chosen by Knight; this argument is without merit.Â  Furthermore, the language 
  of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 does not allow an employer to dictate the medical 
  treatment of injured employees.Â  Our reading of the statute reveals that it 
  requires only that the employer/carrier pay for treatment during the life of 
  the injured employee.
Accordingly, based on the foregoing reasons, 
  the decision of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
CURETON and ANDERSON, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2] 
     Section 42-15-80 states, in pertinent part, as follows:
  
  After an injury and so long as he claims compensation, 
    the employee, if so requested by his employer or ordered by the Commission, 
    shall submit himself to examination, at reasonable times and places, by a 
    duly qualified physician or surgeon designated and paid by the employer or 
    the Commission. Â The employee shall have the right to have present at such 
    examination any duly qualified physician or surgeon provided and paid by him. 
  
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-80 (1985).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Burroughs & Chapin Company, Inc., f/k/a Burroughs and Collins Co.,
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Transportation, Appellant.
In re:
South Carolina Department of Transportation,
Condemnor,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Burroughs & Chapin Company, Inc., f/k/a Burroughs and Collins Co.,
Landowner.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3575
Heard October 11, 2002 â€“ Filed December 
  9, 2002

AFFIRMED IN PART & REVERSED and REMANDED 


  
    
      
B. Michael Brackett, of Columbia; for Appellant.
Michael H. Quinn, of Columbia; 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â Â Â Â  South Carolina Department 
  of Transportation (SCDOT) condemned property owned by Burroughs & Chapin 
  Company (B&C) in Horry County.Â  A jury trial was held to determine the amount 
  of just compensation owed to B&C for the property taken as well as for any 
  diminution of value in the remaining property.Â  SCDOT appeals the juryâ€™sÂ  verdict 
  of $87,510.63, arguing the trial judge erred in the admission of expert witness 
  testimony and in charging the jury in violation of the â€œunit rule.â€Â  Because 
  we find the trial judge erred in charging the jury, we reverse and remand for 
  a new trial.Â  
FACTS
SCDOT condemned 
  property owned by B&C to complete the construction of the Conway Bypass 
  pursuant to its power of eminent domain under the South Carolina Eminent Domain 
  Procedure Act.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-10, et seq. (Supp. 2001).Â Â  SCDOT calculated 
  just compensation for the property at $15,975.00.Â  The condemnation resulted 
  in an acquisition of 10.8 acres; however, another 6.9 acres of B&Câ€™s property 
  were left landlocked.Â  Both tracts were heavily timbered.
At trial, 
  B&C presented two expert witnesses whose testimony was used as evidence 
  of the value of the property.Â  Tracey Knight, a registered forester, testified 
  as an expert in the field of timber appraisal.Â  He stated that his appraisals 
  are often used for the purpose of valuing property to be sold.Â  He also stated 
  that his appraisal was the â€œmarketâ€ value of the timber as of September 1998.Â  
  He testified that the condemned land had 7.8 acres of merchantable timber valued 
  at $30,281.00 and the landlocked portion of the remaining property had timber 
  valued at $28,993.00.Â  Knight testified, however, that it would not be economically 
  feasible to harvest the timber from the landlocked tract of land. 
SCDOT moved 
  [1]  to strike Knightâ€™s testimony on the grounds that it violated the unit 
  rule, [2]  failed to relate the 
  value of the timber to the value of the property, and was based on lost gross 
  revenue or gross profits.Â  The trial judge denied the motion.Â  
After Knightâ€™s testimony, the trial judge gave a cautionary 
  instruction to the jury regarding the value of the timber on B&Câ€™s property.Â  
  The trial judge defined the term â€œfair market valueâ€ and stated that the value 
  of the timber was one component of the property which the jury could use in 
  determining the fair market value of the property.Â  However, he further instructed 
  the jury that: 

. . . if you feel that it is fair and just under the 
  circumstances of this case to add the specific value of a component part of 
  a property, or a portion of that value, such as the timber, you may do so in 
  your calculations, or you may consider the timber value generally in reaching 
  a fair market value determination of the property.Â  This ultimately is your 
  decision to make . . . . 

SCDOT objected to the cautionary instruction on 
  the basis that it allowed the jury to â€œadd these components together.â€Â  
Next, Joe Rosen, a real estate 
  appraiser, testified that the market value of B&Câ€™s land prior to condemnation 
  was $222,050.00, and after condemnation the value of the remaining property 
  was $99,850.00.Â  He testified that just compensation to B&C would be $122,200.00.Â  

In explaining his methodology 
  for the appraisal, Rosen testified that he valued the land as if it had no timber 
  and then added the appraised value of the timber as calculated by Knight.Â  He 
  stated that he found comparable pieces of property, made customary adjustments 
  for the location, size, utilities, land type, etc., and then adjusted each piece 
  by deducting any value of timber on the property.Â  He used the same methodology 
  for appraising the before-condemnation and after-condemnation values of the 
  property.Â  SCDOT moved to strike Rosenâ€™s testimony as violating the unit rule.Â  
  The trial judge denied the motion.Â  
SCDOTâ€™s expert appraised the 
  land at $16,000.00.Â  He testified that he compared the per acre values of several 
  other tracts and made adjustments prior to arriving at that figure.Â  He further 
  stated that he did not do â€œbefore and afterâ€ valuations of B&Câ€™s property 
  because the valuation arrived at for the condemned piece was less than $30,000.00.Â  
  He stated that he did not value the timber separately because the comparable 
  sales all had timber which was considered as part of the value of the property.Â  

The trial judge gave a jury charge very similar to 
  his prior cautionary instruction.Â  He explained the general definition of fair 
  market value and also told the jury on several occasions that it was valuing 
  the property as a whole.Â  However, he again indicated that the jury was free 
  to add the value of the timber to the value of the land to arrive at its decision 
  on just compensation.Â  He also explained that the jury was free to consider 
  the testimony presented, but did not have to rely upon it for making a determination.Â  
  SCDOTâ€™s objection to the charge was overruled.Â  The jury returned a verdict 
  in favor of B&C in the amount of $87,510.63.Â  
DISCUSSION
Admission of Evidence
SCDOT contends the trial 
  judge erred in admitting the testimony of Knight and Rosen.Â  SCDOT asserts the 
  testimony violated the unit rule and that Knightâ€™s testimony made no attempt 
  to equate the value of the timber with the value of the property as a whole.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
The admission or exclusion 
  of expert testimony is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial court. 
  Payton v. Kearse, 329 S.C. 51, 60-61, 495 S.E.2d 205, 211 (1998).Â  Absent 
  a clear abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law, the trial court's 
  ruling will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Hofer v. St. Clair, 298 S.C. 
  503, 513, 381 S.E.2d 736, 742 (1989).Â  
The unit rule states that an award of just compensation 
  may not be reached by assigning separate values to component parts of the property, 
  including separating timber from the land, and requires that improved property 
  be valued as a whole.Â  See 4 Julius Sackman, Nichols on Eminent Domain 
  Â§ 13.09[5] (Rev. 3d ed. 1997); 26 Am. Jur. 2d Eminent Domain Â§ 338 (1996).Â  
  The trial judge relied on the case of City of Hillsborough v. Hughes, 
  538 S.E.2d 586 (N.C. App. 2001), in determining that the admission of B&Câ€™s 
  expertsâ€™ testimony was proper.Â  In Hughes, the North Carolina Court of 
  Appeals found that testimony of the value of timber on condemned property was 
  proper evidence for consideration by the jury.Â  Id. at 589.Â  The court 
  opined that the average person would consider the value of the timber in reaching 
  a decision regarding the value of the property, and, therefore, the value was 
  an appropriate consideration for the jury in determining just compensation for 
  the condemned property.Â  Id. at 588-89.
The Hughes court also cited Cade v. United 
  States, 213 F.2d 138 (4th Cir. 1954), in which the Fourth Circuit Court 
  of Appeals addressed the issue of assigning separate valuations.Â  The court 
  in Cade refused to prohibit testimony as to the separate valuation of 
  enhancing components of the land. The Cade court upheld the expertâ€™s 
  method of valuation.Â  The court reasoned:Â  
The trial judge was correct in thinking that the property 
  should be valued as a whole for the purpose of assessing compensation for the 
  taking; but this does not preclude the admission of testimony showing particular 
  elements of value for consideration by the jury in arriving at the overall value 
  which they are required to find as the basis for compensation.Â  
Id. at 142.Â  While South Carolina has never 
  expressly adopted the unit rule, our supreme court has addressed the admission 
  of testimony regarding the value of mineral deposits on condemned land.Â  In 
  Seaboard Coast Line R.R. v. Harrelson, 262 S.C. 38, 42, 202 S.E.2d 1, 
  3 (1974), the court stated:Â  

The existence of valuable mineral 
  deposits is a proper consideration in ascertaining the value of land taken in 
  an eminent domain proceeding insofar as it influences the market value of the 
  land.Â  This rule, expressed in a great number of decisions and recognized by 
  all the leading textwriters on this subject, has been applied indiscriminately 
  to all forms of mineral deposits, including sand and gravel and limestone.Â Â  


We see no reason why the same logic would not apply 
  to the admission of evidence of the value of timber in this case.Â  Although 
  SCDOT argues the evidence is barred by the unit rule, we believe the better 
  solution is to allow the presentation to the jury of all evidence that bears 
  upon its ultimate responsibility in deciding the fair market value of the property.Â  
  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§28-2-340 (Rev. 1991) (stating evidence which is relevant, 
  material, and competent may be admitted as evidence and considered by the judge 
  or the jury for the purpose of determining the value of the land sought to be 
  condemned and fixing just compensation); Cade, 213 F.2d at 142.Â  While 
  the unit rule precludes the jury from valuing the property as separate units, 
  the value of those units may enhance the fair market value of the property as 
  a whole.Â  Thus, while the property is to be valued as a whole, we do not find 
  that this precludes the admission of testimony showing the separate value of 
  individual elements for consideration by the jury in arriving at the overall 
  value, which is the basis for compensation.
SCDOT further argues the valuation was based on 
  lost gross profits from B&Câ€™s business operations, without accounting for 
  the expenses required to cultivate and harvest the timber.Â  After reviewing 
  the record, we agree that Knightâ€™s testimony failed to account for any expenses 
  associated with planting or cutting the timber.Â  However, this same argument 
  was made in Seaboard and in that case the supreme court noted: â€œWhile 
  this contention is not without some appeal, we think the same is addressed to 
  the weight of the evidence, which was a jury matter, and not to its admissibility.â€Â  
  262 S.C. at 41-42, 202 S.E.2d at 3.Â  We agree that the evidence in this case 
  was for the jury to consider.Â  Accordingly, we find the evidence was properly 
  admitted.
Jury Charge
SCDOT next argues the jury 
  charge was erroneous because it allowed the jury the opportunity to add the 
  value of the timber to the value of the underlying land to reach its decision 
  as to the value of the property as a whole.Â  We agree.
A trial court must charge the current and correct 
  law.Â  McCourt ex rel. McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 306, 457 S.E.2d 
  603, 606 (1995).Â  â€œIn reviewing jury charges for error, we must consider the 
  courtâ€™s jury charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented 
  at trial.Â  If, as a whole, the charges are reasonably free from error, isolated 
  portions which might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.â€Â  Keaton 
  ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 334 S.C. 488, 497, 514 S.E.2d 570, 
  575 (1999) (quoting Bragg v. Hi-Ranger, Inc., 319 S.C. 531, 546, 462 
  S.E.2d 321, 330 (Ct. App. 1995)); see also Waldrup v. Metropolitan 
  Life Ins. Co., 274 S.C. 344, 346, 263 S.E.2d 652, 654 (1980) (stating an 
  appellate court must view the jury charge as a whole before assigning prejudicial 
  error to a discrete portion of the charge).
Here, the trial judge began his charge 
  by defining just compensation and fair market value.Â  He also stated that the 
  jury was not to consider speculative damages, but must â€œconfine your consideration 
  only to those elements which actually affect the propertyâ€™s market value.â€Â  
  The trial judge then explained two methods for computing just compensation; 
  first, by â€œadding to the fair market value of the condemned property . . . an 
  amount which represents the decrease in value of the remaining land,â€ and second, 
  to determine â€œthe fair market value of the landownerâ€™s entire property before 
  the condemnation and subtracting from this amount the fair market value of the 
  property which remained after the taking.â€Â  
The trial judge again explained 
  the definition of fair market value and the fact that compensation to the landowner 
  was the fair market value of the land taken plus any decrease in the value of 
  the land remaining.Â  The trial judge instructed the jury that any damages arising 
  to the remaining land as a result of the condemnation were to be considered 
  in determining just compensation.Â  
Finally, the trial judge again gave an instruction 
  relating to Knightâ€™s and Rosenâ€™s testimony:

Yesterday, you heard testimony about one component of that 
  property, the timber value.Â  I tell you that this information is given to you 
  for your consideration in determining fair market value and you may give it 
  such weight and effect as you, the jury, deem appropriate.

. . . .

In valuing a piece of property, and this is the example I 
  gave you this morning, if I was selling my home, I would not calculate the value 
  by taking a figure that the property is worth and then add to it certain components, 
  such as the fig tree in the back yard, corn which may be in my garden, or a 
  collection of stones which may be in the yard.Â  

These factors may be generally considered in determining a 
  value, but are not usually added one by one.Â  However, if you feel that it 
  is fair and just under the circumstances of this case to add the specific value 
  of a component part of the property, such as the timber, you may do so in your 
  calculations, in whole or in part, or you may consider the timber value 
  generally in reaching a fair market value of the property.Â  This is your decision.Â  

(emphasis added). 
We have found the North 
  Carolina opinion in City of Hillsborough instructive regarding the application 
  of the unit rule.Â  The Hillsborough court concluded that it was proper 
  to allow the jury to consider the value of the timber in reaching its decision 
  regarding the fair market value of the property for just compensation.Â  City 
  of Hillsborough v. Hughes, 538 S.E.2d 586 (N.C. App. 2001). However, the 
  court made it clear that the separate value of the timber was not to be added 
  to the value of the property.Â  Id.Â  The trial judge expressly prohibited 
  the jury from adding the value of the timber which may have been removed from 
  the property.Â  The North Carolina Court of Appeals stated the timber was one 
  â€œfactorâ€ to consider in determining the fair market value.Â  See Hughes, 
  538 S.E.2d at 589.
We agree that the jury is allowed to consider the 
  value of the timber in reaching its decision regarding fair market value of 
  the property.Â  According to section 28-2-370, the jury is to value just compensation 
  as the value of the property taken and the diminution in value of the remaining 
  property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 28-2-370 (Supp. 2001).Â  The trial judgeâ€™s charge 
  was correct to the extent that it stated the jury must find the fair market 
  value of the property, which is what a willing buyer will pay a willing seller.Â  
  The trial judge was also correct in allowing the jury to consider the testimony 
  regarding the value of the timber.Â  However, in this case, the trial judgeâ€™s 
  charge went beyond the charge affirmed in the Hughes decision.Â  The trial 
  judge erred by specifically stating the jury may add the value of the timber 
  to the value of the land if it so chose.Â  This is not the proper method for 
  reaching a decision regarding just compensation under section 28-2-370.Â  While 
  it is clear that the jury did not add the full value of the timber to the land 
  value as testified to by Rosen, we cannot say that the erroneous charge did 
  not affect the amount of the verdict.
CONCLUSION
We find Rosenâ€™s and Knightâ€™s 
  testimony was probative and relevant to the juryâ€™s ultimate purpose of determining 
  the market value of the property as a whole.Â  However, it was improper to charge 
  the jury that values of the separate elements of the property can be added together 
  to determine the value of the property as a whole.Â  Accordingly, the judgment 
  is 
AFFIRMED IN PART & REVERSED AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY and HOWARD, JJ., concur.



 
   
    [1] Prior to trial, SCDOT filed a motion in limine to exclude 
    the testimony of B&Câ€™s expert witnesses claiming both expertsâ€™ testimony 
    violated the unit rule.Â  SCDOT also sought to exclude Knightâ€™s testimony because 
    it was a calculation of lost gross profits and unrelated to the market value 
    of the land.Â  The trial judge denied SCDOTâ€™s motions.Â Â  

 
   
    [2] The unit rule prohibits an award of compensation by assigning separate 
    values to component parts of the property and then adding them together to 
    reach the value of the whole property. See 4 Julius Sackman, Nichols 
    on Eminent Domain Â§ 13.09[5] (Rev. 3d ed. 1997); 26 Am. Jur. 2d Eminent 
    Domain Â§ 338 (1996).Â

title: Burroughs v. Worsham
description: This case involves the analysis of the doctrine "loss of chance of survival" as applied in a medical malpractice death case.  Additionally, future damages, evidentiary issues, jury charges, and inconsistent verdict principles are analyzed.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Yolanda Burroughs, individually, and as Personal Representative of the Estate 
  of James Burroughs, deceased, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
John W. Worsham, M.D.; Terrell T. Leeke, M.D.; and Fairview Family Practice,
Defendants,
Of whom John W. Worsham, M.D. and Fairview Family Practice are
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3576
Heard November 5, 2002 â€“ Filed December 
  9, 2002

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John Hamilton Smith, of Charleston; Ruskin C. Foster 
  and John C. Bradley, Jr., both of Columbia, for Appellants.
Susan C. Rosen and Richard S. Rosen, both of Charleston; 
  Jeffrey J. Kroll and Isobel S. Thomas, both of Chicago, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Yolanda Burroughs, individually and as personal representative 
  for James Burroughsâ€™ (Burroughs) estate, brought suit against Dr. John W. Worsham 
  and Fairview Family Practice (collectively referred to as â€œAppellantsâ€) for 
  medical malpractice.Â  She alleged causes of action for wrongful death, survival, 
  and loss of consortium.Â  The jury awarded $3,500,000 each for the survival and 
  wrongful death actions.Â  The jury determined the decedent and Appellants were 
  each fifty percent at fault.Â  The jury found for Appellants on the loss of consortium 
  claim.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Burroughs received a bachelorâ€™s degree, masterâ€™s degree, and doctorate in theology.Â  
  While serving as a missionary in Mexico, Burroughs met Yolanda, whom he married 
  in 1984.Â  They later had two children.Â  After marrying, the couple moved back 
  to the United States, and eventually settled in Greenville to be close to Burroughsâ€™ 
  ill father.
Burroughs began working for the Hyatt Corporation as a night audit 
  supervisor for $6.50 an hour.Â  He was subsequently promoted to income auditor, 
  to paymaster, to general cashier, to systems administrator, to systems specialist, 
  and then to systems analyst.Â  Burroughs was promoted in 1996 to Management Information 
  Systems Manager.Â  Finally, in May 1997, he was transferred to the corporate 
  headquarters in Chicago, where he became an analyst on special programs and 
  applications making $38,000.00 per year.
While residing in Greenville, Burroughs was a patient at Fairview 
  Family Practice, which was owned by Dr. Worsham and Dr. Terrell T. Leeke.Â  In 
  1990, Burroughs went to Dr. Leeke, who referred him to a gastroenterologist.Â  
  Burroughs was diagnosed with a bleeding ulcer.Â  Burroughsâ€™ first visit to Dr. 
  Worsham was in 1992 for treatment of poison ivy.Â  In 1993, Burroughs went back 
  to the gastroenterologist and was diagnosed as having a propensity for ulcers 
  and suffering from gastritis and duodenitis.
 Burroughs was next seen by Dr. Worsham on April 12, 1995, to determine 
  the cause of his lower abdominal pain.Â  A hemoglobin test was performed and 
  it indicated that Burroughs had a low hemoglobin count.Â  Dr. Worsham prescribed 
  ulcer medication, but provided no further treatment nor did he follow up on 
  the hemoglobin count.
 In August 1995, Burroughs returned to Fairview with abdominal pain.Â  
  He was examined by Dr. Worsham and was diagnosed with acute bacterial prostatitis, 
  for which an antibiotic was prescribed.Â  Burroughs failed to follow-up for re-examination.
 Dr. Worsham gave Burroughs a physical examination in February 1996.Â  
  Burroughs continued having abdominal pain.Â  Dr. Worsham informedÂ  Burroughs 
  that he did not have any significant medical problems, but was anemic.Â  Burroughs 
  was prescribed iron and Citrucel.Â  Dr. Worsham instructed Burroughs to return 
  for a complete blood count in four weeks.Â  According to Dr. Worsham, Burroughs 
  did not go back for the four-week follow-up appointment.
 Five months later, Burroughs returned with severe abdominal pain.Â  
  Dr. Worsham did another blood test and again diagnosed Burroughs as having acute 
  bacterial prostatitis.Â  In his medical note, Dr. Worsham wrote: â€œ[Burroughs] 
  has a deep seeded [sic] fear of either prostate or stomach cancer . . . .â€Â  
  Dr. Worsham additionally diagnosed Burroughs with â€œcancer phobia.â€Â  Dr. Worsham 
  directed Burroughs to call the next day for his lab results and to make an appointment 
  to see Dr. Worsham in two weeks.Â  Neither Dr. Worsham nor Burroughs followed 
  up on the lab results.
Burroughs subsequently saw Dr. Worsham in October 1996.Â  He complained 
  of right side abdominal pain, dizziness, and weakness.Â  Dr. Worsham believed 
  Burroughs had a kidney stone and tests were performed which came back normal.Â  
  Burroughs returned the following day with continued pain.Â  Dr. Worsham felt 
  a bulge in Burroughsâ€™ lower right abdomen.Â  He concluded Burroughs had an incisional 
  hernia over an old appendectomy scar.
Burroughs was referred to Dr. Joseph C. McAlhany, 
  a general surgeon, for evaluation of his condition.Â  Dr. McAlhany noted the 
  pain was â€œjust some strain secondary to the previous appendectomy scar.â€Â  He 
  prescribed anti-inflammatory agents and heat.Â  Further, he instructed Burroughs 
  to return for a recheck in two to three weeks.Â  Burroughs failed to show up 
  for the follow-up office appointment with Dr. McAlhany.
In April 1997, Burroughs returned to Fairview with abdominal pain.Â  
  Because Dr. Worsham was no longer with the practice, Dr. Leeke treated Burroughs.Â  
  Dr. Leeke determined Burroughs was suffering from abdominal pain and chronic 
  anemia.Â  He prescribed Burroughsâ€™ usual ulcer medications.
Approximately two weeks later, Burroughs moved to Chicago for his 
  promotion with Hyatt Hotels Corporation.Â  On November 3, 1997, Burroughs sought 
  treatment in the emergency room of Edward Hospital for severe lower abdominal 
  pain, dizziness, and diarrhea.Â  He was admitted to the hospital.Â  A CT scan 
  showed a mass in the lower abdomen.Â  Burroughs was diagnosed as having colon 
  cancer.
 Several surgeries were performed in an attempt to remove much of 
  the cancer.Â  However, by the time it was diagnosed, the cancer had spread throughout 
  the abdomen.Â  Burroughsâ€™ cancer was incurable.Â  He and his family returned to 
  Ware Shoals, where Burroughs received treatment and hospice care.Â  Burroughs 
  died in May 1999.
 Yolanda originally brought this action against Fairview, Dr. Worsham, 
  and Dr. Leeke.Â  Dr. Leeke was dismissed by a directed verdict, and the initial 
  trial ended in a mistrial.Â  The case was retried against Appellants.Â  The jury 
  determined Appellants and Burroughs were each fifty percent liable.Â  The jury 
  awarded $3,500,000 on both the survival and wrongful death actions.Â  The jury 
  found for Appellants on the loss of consortium claim.Â  Appellantsâ€™ motions for 
  judgment notwithstanding the verdict and a new trial absolute were denied.
ISSUES

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial judge err in admitting Dr. Bart Greenâ€™s 
  testimony over Worshamâ€™s objection because South Carolina does not recognize 
  the â€œloss of chance of survivalâ€ doctrine?
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in admitting testimony 
  from Burroughsâ€™ employer regarding possible future promotions and salary ranges, 
  and in allowing testimony by an economist, who relied on these figures for calculation 
  of future damages?
III.Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in refusing to allow Worsham, 
  as referring doctor, to testify as to what he expected Dr. McAlhany to do in 
  evaluating and diagnosing Burroughsâ€™ condition pursuant to the referral?
IV.Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in refusing to permit Worsham 
  to testify that his review of Dr. McAlhanyâ€™s chart showed no entry indicating 
  Burroughs returned for a follow-up visit?
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in failing to properly charge 
  the jury regarding the standard of care to which Worsham should be held? 
VI.Â Â Â Â  Were the jury verdicts in this case inconsistent, 
  where the jury found damages for wrongful death but no damages for loss of consortium?

STANDARD OF 
  REVIEW
I.Â  Admission of 
  Expert Testimony
The admission or exclusion of expert testimony is 
  a matter within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Payton v. Kearse, 
  329 S.C. 51, 495 S.E.2d 205 (1998); Means v. Gates, 348 S.C. 161, 558 
  S.E.2d 921 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  A trial courtâ€™s ruling to exclude or admit expert 
  testimony will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear abuse of discretion.Â  
  Mizell v. Glover, ___S.C.Â Â  , 570 S.E.2d 176 (2002); Means, 
  348 S.C. at 166, 558 S.E.2d at 923; see also Lee v. Seuss, 318 
  S.C. 283, 457 S.E.2d 344 (1995) (admission of expert testimony is within sound 
  discretion of trial judge and will not be overruled absent finding of abuse 
  of discretion and prejudice to complaining party).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs 
  when there is an error of law or a factual conclusion that is without evidentiary 
  support.Â  Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 
  S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2001).
II.Â  Exclusion of 
  Testimony
It is well settled that the admission and rejection 
  of testimony are matters largely within the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion, 
  the exercise of which will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that 
  discretion.Â  Pike v. South Carolina Depâ€™t ofÂ  Transp., 343 S.C. 224, 
  540 S.E.2d 87 (2000); Commerce Ctr. of Greenville, Inc. v. W. Powers McElveen 
  & Assocs., Inc., 347 S.C. 545, 556 S.E.2d 718 (Ct. App. 2001); see 
  also Gamble v. International Paper Realty Corp., 323 S.C. 367, 474 
  S.E.2d 438 (1996) (admission or exclusion of evidence is matter within sound 
  discretion of trial court and, absent clear abuse, will not be disturbed on 
  appeal). To warrant reversal, the appellant â€œmust show both the error of the 
  ruling and resulting prejudice.â€Â  Recco Tape and Label Co. v. Barfield, 
  312 S.C. 214, 216, 439 S.E.2d 838, 840 (1994); see also Carlyle v. 
  Tuomey Hosp., 305 S.C. 187, 407 S.E.2d 630 (1991) (proof that an error caused 
  the appellant prejudice is a prerequisite to reversal based on error where the 
  trial courtâ€™s discretion is involved).Â  In order for this Court to reverse a 
  case based on the erroneous admission or exclusion of evidence, prejudice must 
  be shown.Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 485 S.E.2d 903 (1997); Commerce 
  Ctr., 347 S.C. at 559, 556 S.E.2d at 726; see also Potomac Leasing 
  Co. v. Bone, 294 S.C. 494, 497, 366 S.E.2d 26, 28 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œBefore 
  the Court of Appeals will reverse a judgment for an alleged error in the exclusion 
  of evidence, the appellant must show prejudice.â€).
III.Â  Jury Charge
It is not error for the trial judge to refuse a specific request to charge 
  when the substance of the request is included in the general instructions.Â  
  Varnadore v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 289 S.C. 155, 345 S.E.2d 711 (1986); 
  Brown v. Stewart, 348 S.C. 33, 557 S.E.2d 676 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In reviewing 
  a jury charge for alleged error, this Court must consider the charge as a whole, 
  in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.Â  Keaton ex rel. Foster 
  v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 334 S.C. 488, 514 S.E.2d 570 (1999).
A trial court must charge the current and correct law.Â  Welch v. Epstein, 
  342 S.C. 279, 536 S.E.2d 408 (Ct. App. 2000); see also Brown v. Smalls, 
  325 S.C. 547, 481 S.E.2d 444 (Ct. App. 1997) (trial judge is required to charge 
  current and correct law applicable to issues presented).Â  A jury charge is correct 
  if, when the charge is read as a whole, it contains the correct definition and 
  adequately covers the law.Â  Keaton, 334 S.C. at 495-96, 514 S.E.2d at 
  574.Â  The substance of the law is what must be instructed to the jury, not any 
  particular verbiage.Â  Id. at 496, 514 S.E.2d at 574.Â  A jury charge which 
  is substantially correct and covers the law does not require reversal.Â  Id.Â  
  To entitle an appellant to reversal, the trial courtâ€™s instructions must be 
  not only erroneous, but also prejudicial.Â  Arkwright Mills v. Clearwater 
  Mfg. Co., 217 S.C. 530, 61 S.E.2d 165 (1950).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  ADMISSION OF 
  EXPERT TESTIMONY
A.Â Â Â Â Â  â€œLoss of Chance of Survivalâ€
Worsham contends the admission of Dr. Bart Greenâ€™s testimony was 
  improper because it did not meet the â€œmost probableâ€ standard for recovery and 
  the testimony merely presented a â€œloss of chance of survival,â€ which is not 
  recognized in South Carolina.Â  We find the trial judge properly admitted the 
  testimony.
In his deposition, Dr. Green testified:

Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Doctor, do you have an opinion, based upon a reasonable 
  degree of certainty, as to whether or not Mr. Burroughs[â€™] chances of cure and 
  survivability would have been greater had they been detected, colon cancer, 
  in February of â€™96?

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

[A]:Â Â  Yes.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  And what is that opinion?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  Colon cancer in general, if diagnosed earlier, at 
  an earlier stage, has a much higher survivability than--than late stage as it 
  was when I was involved in his care.
  
. . . . 
  
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  Do you have an opinion, Doctor, based upon a reasonable 
  degree of certainty, as to whether or not it is most probably true that Jim 
  Burroughs, his chance for cure and survival, would have been greater if the 
  colon cancer was detected in July of â€™96?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes.

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .

Q:Â Â Â Â Â  And what is your opinion?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  My opinion is if it would have been detected at 
  that time, it would have been in an earlier stage and been more curable.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  And does that opinion hold true for October of â€™96 
  and April of â€™97 as well?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  Yes.

The specific testimony of Dr. Green to which Worsham objects is merely 
  a portion of his overall testimony regarding whether Worsham should have diagnosed 
  and treated the colon cancer and, if found earlier, whether Burroughs would 
  have survived.Â  The testimony is certainly relevant to the nature and character 
  of the injuries, which were the natural and proximate consequences of Worshamâ€™s 
  failure to diagnose in this case.
While the portion of testimony taken in isolation may 
  not have met the â€œmost probablyâ€ standard of proof required to demonstrate probable 
  cause, we find it was relevant and properly admitted.Â  See Martin 
  v. Mobley, 253 S.C. 103, 109, 169 S.E.2d 278, 281 (1969) (â€œThe fact that 
  the doctor had not had opportunity to consider whether the plaintiffâ€™s permanent 
  disability was more or less than that which generally followed such a condition 
  and operation affected, we think, only the weight and not the admissibility 
  of the proffered evidence.â€).Â  Additionally, there was sufficient evidence to 
  support the juryâ€™s verdict that Burroughsâ€™ death was â€œmost probablyâ€ the result 
  of the failure to diagnose his cancer earlier and not merely a â€œloss of chance 
  of survival.â€
Our Supreme Court specifically rejected the â€œloss of 
  chanceâ€ doctrine in Jones v. Owings, 318 S.C. 72, 456 S.E.2d 371 (1995).Â  
  The Jones Court concluded:

After a thorough review of the â€œloss of chanceâ€ 
  doctrine, we decline to adopt the doctrine and maintain our traditional approach.Â  
  We are persuaded that â€œthe loss of chance doctrine is fundamentally at odds 
  with the requisite degree of medical certitude necessary to establish a causal 
  link between the injury of a patient and the tortious conduct of a physician.â€Â  
  Legal responsibility in this approach is in reality assigned based on the mere 
  possibility that a tortfeasorâ€™s negligence was a cause of the ultimate 
  harm.Â  This formula is contrary to the most basic standards of proof which undergird 
  the tort system.

Id. at 77, 456 S.E.2d at 374 (citations omitted) (emphasis in original).
The â€œloss of chanceâ€ doctrine, in the context of medical 
  malpractice, â€œpermits a recovery when the delay in proper diagnosis or treatment 
  of a medical condition results in the patient being deprived of a less [than] 
  even chance of surviving or recovering.â€Â  Id. at 75, 456 S.E.2d at 373.Â  
  The Court noted that the decedentâ€™s chance of survival was never above fifty 
  percent, even if his lung cancer had been diagnosed earlier.Â  Id. at 
  74, 456 S.E.2d at 372.Â  The Court maintained South Carolinaâ€™s traditional approach 
  that, in order to recover based on medical malpractice, the plaintiff must show 
  the negligence of the physician â€œmost probablyâ€ caused the injury or death.Â  
  Id. (citing Sherer v. James, 290 S.C. 404, 351 S.E.2d 148 (1986)).
In Haselden v. Davis, 341 S.C. 486, 534 S.E.2d 295 (Ct. App. 2000), 
  cert. granted (January 11, 2001), this Court had the opportunity to determine 
  whether evidence which demonstrates the negligence of a physician in failing 
  to diagnose the decedent, who would have had a greater than fifty percent chance 
  of survival except for the negligence of the doctor, satisfies the â€œmost probableâ€ 
  standard.Â  We concluded that, when an individual would have had a greater than 
  fifty percent chance of survival if the physician had properly advised the decedent 
  at an earlier time, evidence of the failure to do so satisfies the â€œmost probablyâ€ 
  requirement for causation.Â  Id. at 495, 534 S.E.2d at 300.
In the instant case, Dr. Randolph Baily testified 
  regarding Burroughsâ€™ chance of survival had the cancer been diagnosed earlier.Â  
  The following colloquy is demonstrative of his opinions:

Q.Â Â Â Â Â  Doctor, in February of 1996, when he had that physical 
  exam, do you have an opinion, based upon a reasonable degree of certainty, as 
  to whether or not Jim Burroughs would have survived if he was diagnosed and 
  properly treated on that date?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Yes, sir, I believe he would have.
  
. . . . 
  
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  Doctor, do you have an opinion if that was diagnosed, 
  the colon cancer, in February of 1996, if Jim Burroughs would have had a normal 
  life expectancy?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  I believe he would have.Â  Had the tumor been removed, 
  then he could have had a normal life expectancy, yes.

Dr. Baily was asked the question regarding whether Burroughs would have survived 
  and had a normal life expectancy if the cancer had been diagnosed in July of 
  1996, and October of 1996.Â  In both cases, he responded that Burroughs would 
  have likely survived and would have enjoyed a normal life expectancy.
During redirect examination, the following exchange 
  took place:

Q.Â Â Â Â Â  Is it your opinion that in February, July and October, 
  Mr. Burroughsâ€™ condition was more likely than not curable?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Absolutely.
Q.Â Â Â Â Â  And Doctor, do you have an opinion during those 
  relevant time periods if it was diagnosed and treated would he have survived 
  and lived a normal life?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  I believe itâ€™s more likely than not that he would 
  have, yes, sir.

The above testimony demonstrates that Burroughs would have had a 
  greater than fifty percent chance of survival if the colon cancer had been diagnosed 
  in February 1996, July 1996, or October 1996.Â  Therefore, the evidence supports 
  the inference that the failure by Dr. Worsham to diagnose Burroughsâ€™ condition 
  â€œmost probablyâ€ resulted in his death and not merely in a â€œloss of chance of 
  survival.â€
We note the trial judge properly charged the jury regarding the appropriate 
  standard of proof that must be met by Burroughs in order for the jury to award 
  damages.Â  The trial judge instructed:

Now, ladies and gentlemen, when the opinions of a medical 
  expert are relied upon to establish a causal connection between negligence and 
  an injury, the expert must state with reasonable certainty that in his professional 
  opinion the injuries most probably resulted, or the death most probably resulted 
  from the alleged negligence of the defendant.Â  Or that expert must use words 
  that would mean to you the same thing, that the death most probably resulted 
  as the alleged negligence of the defendant.

The trial judge properly admitted the testimony of Dr. Green.Â  Concomitantly, 
  there was sufficient evidence to support the juryâ€™s determination that Worshamâ€™s 
  diagnosis was â€œmost probablyâ€ the proximate cause of Burroughsâ€™ death.
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Future Damages/Future 
  Salary
Worsham argues the trial court erred in admitting testimony of Burroughsâ€™ possible 
  future salary, which included several promotions and salary increases, as being 
  too speculative.Â  We find the testimony was properly admitted for consideration 
  by the jury.
â€œUnder current South Carolina law, the standard of admissibility for evidence 
  of future damages is â€˜any evidence which tends to establish the nature, character, 
  and extent of injuries which are the natural and proximate consequences of the 
  defendantâ€™s acts . . . if otherwise competent.â€™â€Â  Pearson v. Bridges, 
  344 S.C. 366, 372, 544 S.E.2d 617, 620 (2001) (quoting Martin v. Mobley, 
  253 S.C. 103, 109, 169 S.E.2d 278, 281-82 (1969)).Â  The â€œmost probableâ€ standard 
  required to prove causation is not the standard to be applied in determining 
  the admissibility of evidence of future damages.Â  Id. at 371, 544 S.E.2d 
  at 619.Â  Furthermore, â€œwhether future medical expenses are â€˜reasonably certainâ€™ 
  to occur is also the incorrect standard to use in determining admissibility.â€Â  
  Id.Â  â€œWhether future damages are â€˜reasonably certainâ€™ to occur is the 
  standard of proof for future damages, not the standard of admissibility.â€Â  
  Id. at 371-72, 544 S.E.2d at 619 (italics in original).
In Pearson, the medical expert testified that four possible scenarios 
  could result from the alleged malpractice.Â  For each scenario, he presented 
  a declining statistical chance of occurrence and the possible damages which 
  could result.Â  The Supreme Court explained:

The evidence of the medical expenses of scenarios two, three, 
  and four was admissible.Â  These scenarios tended to establish the extent of 
  Pearsonâ€™s injuries.Â  The fact that Pearsonâ€™s experts testified that the possibilities 
  of scenarios two, three, and four occurring were 30 percent or less went to 
  the weight of the evidence not its admissibility.Â  Whether Pearson proved the 
  expenses were â€œreasonably certainâ€ to occur so she would be entitled to an award 
  of future damages was a question for the jury to determine.

Pearson, 344 S.C. at 373, 544 S.E.2d at 620 (internal citations omitted).
In the instant case, the testimony provided a possible scenario for future 
  advancement and income for Burroughs.Â  James Barnish, the Assistant Vice-President 
  of hotel accounting for the Hyatt, chronicled the possible path of advancement 
  within Hyatt.Â  He stated:

James had a good career up to the time that he moved to 
  the â€“ to the corporate office, and what I personally had thought would be his 
  next logical step would be to work for me in one of my other areas of responsibility 
  for the IT department in the corporate office, and James had â€“ I knew James 
  had a real interest in the IT side, or the computer side of the business, and 
  he preferred to go that route than the hotel accounting route, and itâ€™s difficult 
  to hang onto people in that area, and I would have seen him progressing within 
  the organization as long as he wanted to stay with the company, that he would 
  have made it to a manger [sic], director and eventually an officer type level 
  position, because he had the years of service, and Hyatt is very, very big on 
  promoting from within.

Barnish was asked: â€œWere the promotions outlined with what 
  you believed most probably would have happened for James Burroughs had he not 
  left?â€Â  Barnish answered, â€œYes.â€Â  Barnish declared that the positions and salaries 
  presented to Burroughsâ€™ economist for use in determining lost future wages were 
  correct.Â  Dr. Charles Alford, an economist, opined that, given the promotion 
  track provided by Barnish, the present value of Burroughsâ€™ future wages was 
  $1,558,749.
As in Pearson, whether the future damages in the case sub judice 
  were established with â€œreasonable certaintyâ€ was a decision for the jury and 
  did not impact the admissibility of the evidence.Â  We iterate for the edification 
  of the Bench and Bar that the standard for the admission of evidence is different 
  from the standard of proof to be used by the jury in determining whether to 
  assess damages.Â  The question in this case, as in Pearson, is whether 
  the evidence was properly admitted, not whether the evidence was sufficient 
  to support a verdict including future damages.Â  We conclude the evidence was 
  properly admitted, and whether the damages were â€œreasonably certainâ€ to occur 
  was a decision for the jury.
II.Â  FAILURE TO ALLOW 
  WORSHAMâ€™S TESTIMONY
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Expectations Regarding Referral
Dr. Worsham claims the trial judge erred by refusing to allow him 
  to testify as to what he expected Dr. McAlhany to do in evaluating and diagnosing 
  Burroughs pursuant to Worshamâ€™s referral.Â  We find no prejudicial error by the 
  trial judge.
Worsham sought to introduce testimony regarding his expectations 
  of what Dr. McAlhany would do to diagnose Burroughsâ€™ condition after Worshamâ€™s 
  referral.Â  The testimony excluded was never proffered to the court.Â  As there 
  was no proffer, Worsham cannot demonstrate how he was prejudiced by its exclusion.Â  
  See Baber v. Greenville County, 327 S.C. 31, 41, 488 S.E.2d 314, 
  319 (1997) (â€œAbsent a proffer, it is impossible for this Court to determine 
  the effect of the excluded testimony.â€).
Moreover, on direct examination during the plaintiffâ€™s case-in-chief, 
  Dr. Worsham testified:

A:Â Â Â Â Â  I did not remember James Burroughs until I saw his 
  deposition and I recognized his face, but as far as remembering him specifically, 
  had we run into each other somewhere, no, I canâ€™t say that I truly remembered 
  him.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  And just so weâ€™re clear, you were his main treating 
  doctor, correct?
A:Â Â Â Â Â  Thatâ€™s correct.
Q:Â Â Â Â Â  You did not remember him?
A.Â Â Â Â Â  I did not remember him specifically, no.

This testimony demonstrates with remarkable clarity the inability of Dr. Worsham 
  to testify personally about his expectations in regard to the referral of Burroughs 
  to Dr. McAlhany.
In an action for medical malpractice, the fact that a family practitioner 
  referred the patient to a specialist does not, in and of itself, establish due 
  care.Â Â Â  See Marchese v. Monaco, 145 A.2d 809 (N.J. Super. Ct. 
  App. Div. 1958).Â  In spite of referral, a family practitioner still owes the 
  patient the duty to exercise that degree of knowledge, care, skill, and learning 
  possessed and exercised under the same or similar circumstances by a competent 
  family practitioner.Â  Id.
The mere fact that a family practitioner acts on the advice of another 
  physician, even though a specialist, does not constitute a defense to an action 
  based on unskilled treatment.Â  Id.Â  This record is replete with testimony 
  emanating from various physicians concluding that Dr. Worsham, in diagnosing 
  and treating the medical condition of Burroughs, failed to exercise that degree 
  of knowledge, care, skill, and learning possessed and exercised by an ordinary, 
  careful, and prudent family practitioner under the same or similar circumstances.
On the merits, the testimony elicited from Dr. McAlhany demonstrated 
  that Burroughs was referred to him for treatment of an incisional hernia, and 
  that he examined Burroughs consistent with that referral.Â  Dr. McAlhany testified 
  he would do further testing in the event the reason for the referral was not 
  proper or if he was asked.Â  He professed that he was not informed of the patientâ€™s 
  history of abdominal pain nor was he informed of Burroughsâ€™ anemia at the time 
  of the referral.
Dr. Worsham had ample opportunity to cross-examine Dr. McAlhany regarding whether 
  he did further examination and whether it was something he was expected to do 
  when a patient was referred to him.Â  Based on the testimony presented, we find 
  Worsham was not prejudiced by the exclusion of testimony regarding his expectations 
  as to Dr. McAlhany.Â  See Means v. Gates, 348 S.C. 161, 166, 558 
  S.E.2d 921, 924 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œBefore the Court of Appeals will reverse a 
  judgment for an alleged error in the exclusion of evidence, the appellant must 
  show prejudice.â€).Â  The trial court did not abuse its discretion in excluding 
  Worshamâ€™s testimony regarding his expectations of Dr. McAlhanyâ€™s examination.
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Burroughsâ€™ Failure to Follow-Up
Worsham maintains the judge erred in refusing to allow him to testify 
  that his review of Dr. McAlhanyâ€™s chart indicated Burroughs never returned for 
  a follow-up visit.Â  We determine the exclusion of this testimony was harmless 
  as it would have been cumulative to other testimony in the record.
Worsham sought to testify, based on his reading of Dr. McAlhanyâ€™s 
  report, that Burroughs never returned for a follow-up visit.Â  The trial court 
  refused to allow Worsham to interpret Dr. McAlhanyâ€™s records when Dr. McAlhany 
  had already testified.
When Dr. McAlhany was asked whether Burroughs returned 
  for a follow-up visit, he testified that Burroughs never returned.Â  This point 
  was brought out several times by Worshamâ€™s counsel during cross-examination.Â  
  Therefore, the excluded testimony would have been merely cumulative to testimony 
  already in the record.Â  â€œGenerally, there is no abuse of discretion where the 
  excluded testimony is merely cumulative of other evidence proffered to the jury.â€Â  
  Commerce Center of Greenville, Inc. v. W. Powers McElveen & Assocs., 
  Inc., 347 S.C. 545, 559, 556 S.E.2d 718, 726 (Ct. App. 2001); see also 
  Ott v. Pittman, 320 S.C. 72, 463 S.E.2d 101 (Ct. App. 1995) (upholding 
  trial judgeâ€™s decision to exclude particular witnessâ€™s testimony, which the 
  Court of Appeals characterized as â€œcumulative to that of other witnessesâ€).
The trial court did not abuse its discretion in excluding Worshamâ€™s 
  testimony that Burroughs missed his follow-up appointment with Dr. McAlhany.
III.Â  JURY CHARGE
Worsham asserts the trial court erred in failing to specifically 
  charge that the standard of care his actions must be measured against was that 
  of an ordinary, careful, and prudent physician â€œin his specialtyâ€ under the 
  same or similar circumstances.Â  We find that when the jury charges, including 
  the two clarifying charges, are read as a whole, the trial judge properly enounced 
  the standard of review by which Worshamâ€™s actions should be measured.
The trial judge originally charged the jury regarding 
  the standard of care as follows:

Now, in this case I will charge you that the law in regard 
  to diagnosing a patient is that the degree of skill and care a physician must 
  use in diagnosing a condition is that which would be exercised by a competent 
  practitioner in the defendant doctorâ€™s field of medicine.Â  And I will charge 
  you that in this case the question is whether Dr. Worsham, in making a diagnosis, 
  deviated from the applicable standard of care, either by not employing a particular 
  procedure or by not ordering a particular test.Â  And that is to be determined 
  by what an ordinary, careful, and prudent physician would have done under the 
  same or similar circumstances in this case.
. . . What the law does require of a physician is this, 
  that in the practice of -- he shall exercise that degree of knowledge, care 
  and skill ordinarily possessed by members of his profession in good standing 
  under the same or similar circumstances.

(emphasis added).Â  Appellants did not object to the charge 
  as given.
The jury submitted a question to the judge which read: â€œWe 
  are confused about what the law states the M.D. must do, as a minimum, to meet 
  the standards of care.â€Â  Appellantsâ€™ attorneys then requested a charge to the 
  jury â€œadd[ing] the defendant doctorâ€™s field of medicine.â€Â  The trial judge gave 
  the following clarifying charge:
In this case, the law in South Carolina is, the question 
  of whether a physician in making a diagnosis deviated from the applicable standard 
  of care, either by not employing a particular procedure or by not administering 
  a particular test, is to be determined by what an ordinary, careful and prudent 
  physician would have done under the same or similar circumstances.
The jury submitted a second question requesting further clarification 
  of the standard of care and its application in this case.Â  The judge charged 
  the jury:

Now, doctors must do what an ordinary, reasonable, prudent doctor would do under 
  the same or similar circumstances.Â  If a doctor does something or fails to do 
  something that an ordinary, reasonable doctor should have done under the -- 
  under those circumstances then it would be negligence.Â  Okay.
As a general rule, you and I do not know what the standards of care are.Â  Therefore 
  we have to learn or hear what the standards of care are through expert witnesses, 
  or expert testimony what are generally recognized and accepted practices and 
  procedures which should be followed by the average, competent doctor in the 
  defendantâ€™s profession, under the same or similar circumstances.

(emphasis added).Â  Appellants did not object to this charge 
  as given.
In King v. Williams, 276 S.C. 478, 482, 279 
  S.E.2d 618, 620 (1981), the Supreme Court held: â€œThe degree of care which must 
  be observed is, of course, that of an average, competent practitioner acting 
  in the same or similar circumstances.â€Â  Since the King decision, this 
  Court has defined medical malpractice as â€œthe failure of a physician to exercise 
  that degree of care and skill which is ordinarily employed by the profession 
  generally, under similar conditions and in like surrounding circumstances.â€Â  
  Jernigan v. King, 312 S.C. 331, 333, 440 S.E.2d 379, 381 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
  â€œThe standard for recovery has been summarized, â€˜To recover for medical malpractice, 
  a plaintiff must show failure by a physician to exercise that degree of care 
  and skill which is ordinarily employed by the profession under similar conditions 
  and in like circumstances.â€™â€Â  Keaton ex rel. Foster v. Greenville Hosp. 
  Sys., 334 S.C. 488, 496, 514 S.E.2d 570, 574 (1999) (quoting Bonaparte 
  v. Floyd, 291 S.C. 427, 434, 354 S.E.2d 40, 45 (Ct. App. 1987)) (emphasis 
  in original).
While the first clarifying charge fails to specifically 
  state that the standard of care is based on a doctor in the same field of medicine, 
  both the main charge and the second clarifying charge elucidate the jury as 
  to the requirement that Worshamâ€™s actions are to be juxtaposed to those of a 
  doctor in the same field of medicine.Â  In looking at the charges given as a 
  whole, we find no prejudicial error in the clarifying chargeâ€™s failure to indicate 
  that the standard of care is compared to doctors in the same field of medicine.Â  
  See Keaton, 334 S.C. at 497, 514 S.E.2d at 575.
Worsham complains that the testimony establishing the standard of 
  care was not by a medical professional in the area of family medicine, but was 
  explained by an internal medicine specialist and a surgeon.Â  We rule the experts 
  who testified properly detailed the standard of care for a family practitioner 
  based on their knowledge and experiences.
Dr. Daniel Derman is board certified in internal medicine.Â  He testified 
  the standard of care for a family practitioner diagnosing and treating a patient 
  with symptoms of colon cancer is the same as the standard in internal medicine.Â  
  Specifically, he stated: â€œ[F]or primary care in terms of being the first one 
  on the front line, so to speak, who might see a colon cancer, it would not only 
  be the same for family practice as internal medicine, but itâ€™s going to be the 
  same all over the country as well.â€
Dr. Randolph Baily, a colorectal surgeon, detailed his background 
  and how he was qualified to establish the standard of care for family practitioners.Â  
  He testified that he has taught diagnosis and treatment of colon cancer to students 
  and residents in family practice at Baylor College of Medicine and the University 
  of Texas Medical School in Houston.Â  In addition, he declared that diagnosing 
  colon cancer is something taught in medical school to all students regardless 
  of their specialties.Â  According to Dr. Baily, Worshamâ€™s actions failed to meet 
  the appropriate standard of care for diagnosing and treating colon cancer.
Finally, Dr. Meher Medavaram, Burroughsâ€™ family practice doctor in 
  Chicago, testified that the standard of care for family practitioners was consistent 
  throughout the United States.Â  She asserted Worsham failed to properly perform 
  tests to determine the cause of Burroughsâ€™ anemia.Â  She professed the standard 
  of care required the performance of additional tests to rule out colon cancer.
The testimony presented by Burroughsâ€™ expert witnesses 
  established the standard of care for a doctor in family practice.Â  The experts 
  were each qualified to detail the standard of care in family practice.Â  Thus, 
  the testimony was properly admitted.Â  See Means v. Gates, 348 
  S.C. 161, 558 S.E.2d 921 (Ct. App. 2001) (admission or exclusion of expert testimony 
  is matter within sound discretion of trial court, whose decision will not be 
  disturbed on appeal absent abuse of discretion).
We find no error in the jury charge or the testimony by 
  Burroughsâ€™ experts used to establish and clarify the standard of care.
IV.Â  INCONSISTENT 
  VERDICTS
Appellants allege the juryâ€™s verdicts finding 
  them liable for the wrongful death cause of action, but finding no liability 
  for loss of consortium were inconsistent, and, therefore, a new trial should 
  have been ordered.Â  We find the argument raised is not properly preserved.Â  
  Moreover, the assertion fails on the merits, as the causes of action are separate 
  and distinct, and the verdicts were entirely consistent.
The reading of the verdict by the trial judge and any subsequent 
  objections are not included in the Record on Appeal.Â  It is impossible for us 
  to determine whether Appellants raised timely objections to the issue of the 
  inconsistent verdicts.Â  As such, the issue is not properly preserved for review 
  on appeal.Â  See Smith v. Phillips, 318 S.C. 453, 458 S.E.2d 427 
  (1995) (noting appellate court could not consider propriety of juryâ€™s verdict 
  which found neighbor liable for nuisance but awarded no damages, where there 
  was no objection at trial by neighbor or landowner which brought nuisance action, 
  and neither party raised issue on appeal); Stevens v. Allen, 336 S.C. 
  439, 520 S.E.2d 625 (Ct. App. 1999), affâ€™d, 342 S.C. 47, 536 S.E.2d 663 
  (2000) (holding there is no duty imposed on trial judge to question juryâ€™s verdict 
  of liability, but no damages, unless requested to by a party).
The order denying Appellantsâ€™ motions for judgment notwithstanding 
  the verdict and for a new trial absolute is in the Record on Appeal.Â  However, 
  the motions themselves are not.Â  The order incorporates by reference the post-trial 
  motions made during the hearing.Â  Yet, the portion of the hearing in which the 
  motions were made is not included in the Record on Appeal.Â  The order finds 
  the motions not preserved.Â  The only possible reference to this issue is where 
  the judge notes: â€œ[T]he Defendants failed to make a timely objection to the 
  form of the jury verdict thereby waiving same.â€Â  The Record on Appeal does not 
  allow us to determine whether a proper objection or motion for a new trial was 
  made based on this specific issue.Â  Appellants had the burden to furnish a sufficient 
  record from which an intelligent review could be conducted.Â  See D 
  & D Leasing Co. v. Gentry, 298 S.C. 342, 380 S.E.2d 823 (1989) (emphasizing 
  that burden is on appellant to furnish a sufficient record from which an intelligent 
  review can be conducted and finding that appellant did not meet this burden; 
  thus, the appellate court properly dismissed the appeal).
In addition, Appellantsâ€™ claims fail on the merits.Â  
  Under South Carolina law, unlike that of some other states, loss of consortium 
  is an independent action, not derivative.Â  Preer v. Mims, 323 S.C. 516, 
  476 S.E.2d 472 (1996); Stewart v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 341 
  S.C. 143, 533 S.E.2d 597 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œAlthough loss of consortium is an 
  independent action, case law has held the right of action does not accrue until 
  the loss of the services, society and companionship of the spouse has actually 
  occurred, which has been defined as the point when the spouse sustained the 
  injuries.â€Â  Stewart, 341 S.C. at 156, 533 S.E.2d at 604.Â  â€œLoss of consortium 
  arises out of the special relationship between a husband and wife.â€Â  Id.Â  
  â€œAny person may maintain an action for damages arising from an intentional or 
  tortious violation of the right to the companionship, aid, society and services 
  of his or her spouse.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-75-20 (1977).
According to the Wrongful Death Act: â€œWhenever the 
  death of a person shall be caused by the wrongful act, neglect or default of 
  another and the act, neglect or default is such as would, if death had not ensued, 
  have entitled the party injured to maintain an action and recover damages in 
  respect thereof, the person who would have been liable, if death had not ensued, 
  shall be liable to an action for damages.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-51-10 (1977).Â  
  â€œEvery such action shall be for the benefit of the wife or husband and child 
  or children of the person whose death shall have been so caused, and, if there 
  be no such wife, husband, child or children, then for the benefit of the parent 
  or parents, and if there be none such, then for the benefit of the heirs of 
  the person whose death shall have been so caused.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-51-20 
  (Supp. 2001).
This Court has identified factors to be considered 
  in assessing damages under the Wrongful Death Act.Â  â€œThe general elements of 
  damages recoverable are: (1) pecuniary loss, (2) mental shock and suffering, 
  (3) wounded feelings, (4) grief and sorrow, (5) loss of companionship, and (6) 
  deprivation of the use and comfort of the intestateâ€™s society, including the 
  loss of his experience, knowledge, and judgment in managing the affairs of himself 
  and of his beneficiaries.â€Â  Self v. Goodrich, 300 S.C. 349, 351, 387 
  S.E.2d 713, 714 (Ct. App. 1989).
While the factors to consider for damages in a wrongful 
  death action include loss of consortium, we find this is not sufficient to say 
  that a plaintiffâ€™s verdict on wrongful death and a defense verdict on loss of 
  consortium are inconsistent.Â  First, the parties benefiting from the actions 
  may be separate and distinct.Â  Only the spouse may bring a loss of consortium 
  claim.Â  However, the spouse, children, parents, or other heirs may be the beneficiaries 
  of the wrongful death award.
Additionally, the statute establishes that the claim 
  for loss of consortium is to compensate the spouse for â€œtortious violation of 
  the right to the companionship, aid, society and services of his or her spouse.â€Â  
  Â§ 15-75-20.Â  In contrast, a wrongful death claim is to compensate the heirs 
  of a decedent, who, if he had survived, could have brought a personal injury 
  action.Â  Â§ 15-51-10.Â  This Court, as well as the South Carolina Supreme Court, 
  has ruled claims for personal injury and loss of consortium are separate and 
  distinct claims, and a ruling on one does not bar, nor entitle, recovery on 
  the other claim.Â  See, e.g., Graham v. Whitaker, 282 S.C. 
  393, 321 S.E.2d 40 (1984); Page v. Crisp, 303 S.C. 117, 399 S.E.2d 161 
  (Ct. App. 1990).
We find that, as a wrongful death claim is premised on the decedentâ€™s ability 
  to have brought a personal injury claim if he had survived, the rulings in the 
  cases of Graham and Page are apposite and analogous to the present 
  case.Â  Verdicts awarding damages for wrongful death, but finding for the defense 
  on loss of consortium, are not inconsistent.Â  We hold the two claims are separate 
  and distinct, and, as pronounced in Page, â€œ[e]ach litigant was entitled 
  to a verdict based on the law and the evidence.â€Â  Page, 303 S.C. at 119, 
  399 S.E.2d at 162.
CONCLUSION
We rule the testimony of Dr. Green was properly admitted 
  because it did not violate the â€œloss of chance of survivalâ€ doctrine.Â  We find 
  that the testimony regarding Burroughsâ€™ future promotion opportunities and possible 
  salaries was admissible as it explained the extent and nature of Burroughsâ€™ 
  injuries.Â  We further remind the Bench and Bar that the standard of admissibility 
  is different from the standard of proof for evidence of future damages.Â  We 
  hold the trial judge did not err in excluding Worshamâ€™s testimony regarding 
  his expectations of Dr. McAlhanyâ€™s care or Burroughsâ€™ failure to follow up with 
  Dr. McAlhany.Â  Testimony was already in the record, making Worshamâ€™s testimony 
  cumulative and unnecessary.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s charges, when viewed as a whole, 
  were proper and adequate statements of the law of South Carolina regarding the 
  standard of care for a family practitioner.Â  We determine the claims of wrongful 
  death and loss of consortium are separate and distinct causes of action.Â  Apodictically, 
  we conclude the juryâ€™s verdicts, one awarding damages for wrongful death and 
  the other denying damages for loss of consortium, were not inconsistent.Â  Accordingly, 
  the judgment of the Circuit Court is
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and CURETON, J., concur.
