THE STATE 
  OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        FOC Lawshe Limited Partnership, FOC 
          Pee Dee Limited Partnership, and FOC Downtown Limited Partnership, by 
          Fisher Opportunity Corporation, Its General Partner,        
          Appellants/Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        International Paper Company,        
          Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From 
  Georgetown County
  Â Sidney T. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion 
  No.Â  3580
  Heard October 10, 2002 â€“ Filed December 16, 2002

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        E. LeRoy Nettles, Sr. and Marian 
          D. Nettles, of Lake City; for Appellants-Respondents.
Robert L. Widener, of Columbia, 
  and William W. Doar, Jr., of Georgetown; for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  FOC 
  Lawshe Limited Partnership, et al, (collectively FOC Lawshe), brought suit seeking 
  injunctive relief and damages against International Paper Company.Â  FOC Lawshe 
  appeals the trial judgeâ€™s denial of its motion for temporary injunctive relief.Â  
  International Paper appeals the denial of its motion to dismiss pursuant to 
  Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  We affirm the denial of both motions.
FACTS
FOC Lawshe is the 
  owner of a plantation consisting of approximately 841 acres.Â  The Black River 
  bounds FOC Lawsheâ€™s land to the north.Â  International Paper owns large tracts 
  of land, which surround FOC Lawsheâ€™s land to the east, south, and west.Â  FOC 
  Lawshe purchased its land primarily for the purpose of hunting deer and quail.Â  
  FOC Lawshe invested time and money to improve the land to be used for hunting 
  and to stock the property with wildlife.Â  International Paper primarily utilizes 
  its land for growing timber for use in its paper products.Â  However, International 
  Paper leases its property to several hunt clubs to use for hunting deer.Â  During 
  hunting season, the hunt clubs commonly hunt deer on Wednesdays and Saturdays, 
  the same days that FOC Lawshe hunts deer and quail on its plantation.
The hunt clubs that lease the land from 
  International Paper utilize dogs while they are hunting.Â  The dogs are released 
  to chase deer in the direction of the waiting hunters.Â  FOC Lawsheâ€™s hunters 
  are â€œstillâ€ hunters, meaning they set out corn, climb deer stands, and wait 
  for a passing deer.Â  The dogs released by the hunt clubs frequently cross over 
  from International Paperâ€™s lands onto FOC Lawsheâ€™s property and disrupt the 
  hunting by FOC Lawsheâ€™s members and guests.Â  Deer and other wildlife are chased 
  off FOC Lawsheâ€™s property toward the hunt clubs on International Paperâ€™s land.Â  
  The dogs have also raided quail pens on FOC Lawsheâ€™s property, destroying the 
  pens and the animals. 
FOC Lawshe attempted 
  to settle the dispute with the hunt clubs without success.Â  When members of 
  FOC Lawshe contacted individuals at International Paper, they were told that 
  buffer areas were established between the adjoining lands and that the problem 
  would be corrected.Â  However, the use of dogs continued, and the buffer zones 
  proved ineffective.Â  Ruskin Dowdy, an employee of International Paper, told 
  the members of FOC Lawshe the trespassing dogs may be coming from other groups 
  and not the hunt clubs.Â  However, FOC Lawsheâ€™s members collected the collars 
  of nine dogs they found on their property, and believe the collars were from 
  dogs owned by members of the hunt clubs that lease International Paperâ€™s land. 

 FOC Lawshe brought 
  suit against International Paper seeking a temporary restraining order and damages.Â  
  FOC Lawshe based its claim on a theory of nuisance arising from the disruption 
  caused by the trespassing dogs.Â  Neither the hunt clubs nor their members were 
  named as defendants in the action.Â  FOC Lawshe moved for the temporary restraining 
  order when it filed its complaint.Â  International Paper moved to dismiss the 
  action for failing to state a cause of action pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, 
  and for failing to join a necessary party under Rule 19, SCRCP. 
The trial court 
  found FOC Lawshe failed to establish the requirements necessary for issuing 
  a temporary restraining order, and denied its motion.Â  In a separate order, 
  the trial court found the complaint stated a cause of action in nuisance against 
  International Paper and that all necessary parties were joined in the action.Â  
  Accordingly, the court denied International Paperâ€™s motions to dismiss the case. 

STANDARD 
  OF REVIEW
A.Â  Motion to Dismiss
A trial judge may 
  dismiss a claim when the defendant demonstrates the plaintiffâ€™s â€œfailure to 
  state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of actionâ€ in the pleadings filed 
  with the court.Â  Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP. â€œThe trial court must dispose of a motion 
  for failure to state a cause of action based solely upon the allegations set 
  forth on the face of the complaint.â€Â Â  Brown v. Leverette, 291 S.C. 364, 
  366, 353 S.E.2d 697, 698 (1987).Â  â€œThe motion cannot be sustained if facts alleged 
  in the complaint and inferences reasonably deducible therefrom would entitle 
  plaintiff to any relief on any theory of the case.â€Â  Id.Â  All properly 
  pleaded factual allegations are deemed admitted for the purposes of considering 
  a motion for judgment on the pleadings.Â  Russell v. Columbia, 305 S.C. 
  86, 89, 406 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1991).Â  
B.Â  Temporary Injunction
The decision to grant or 
  deny temporary injunctive relief is within the sound discretion of the trial 
  judge and will not be overturned absent an abuse of discretion.Â  City of 
  Columbia v. Pic-A-Flick Video, Inc., 340 S.C. 278, 282, 531 S.E.2d 518, 
  520 (2000).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when a trial court's decision is 
  unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â  Zabinski v. 
  Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 601, 553 S.E.2d 110, 121 (2001).Â  â€œThe 
  sole purpose of a temporary injunction is to preserve the status quo and thus 
  avoid possible irreparable injury to a party pending litigation.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
A.Â  Motion to Dismiss
International Paper 
  contends the trial court erred in denying its motion to dismiss pursuant to 
  Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP. [1] Â  We 
  disagree.
â€œThe traditional concept of a nuisance requires a landowner 
  to demonstrate that the defendant unreasonably interfered with his ownership 
  or possession of the land.â€Â  Silvester v. Spring Valley Country Club, 
  344 S.C. 280, 286, 543 S.E.2d 563, 566 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Nuisance is a substantial 
  and unreasonable interference with the plaintiffâ€™s use and enjoyment of his 
  land.Â  Id.Â  â€œNuisance law is based on the premise that â€˜[e]very citizen 
  holds his property subject to the implied obligation that he will use it in 
  such a way as not to prevent others from enjoying the use of their property.â€™â€Â  
  Clark v. Greenville County, 313 S.C. 205, 209, 437 S.E.2d 117, 119 (1993) 
  (citations omitted).Â  In South Carolina, a landlord cannot be held liable for 
  a nuisance arising from the use of his land when the landlord has no control 
  over the property at the time of the alleged nuisance.Â  See id. 
  at 210, 437 S.E.2d at 119.Â  Conversely, if the landowner maintains complete 
  control of the leased property, he may be liable for the nuisance created 
  by the use of the land.Â  See Peden v. Furman University, 155 S.C. 
  1, 19, 151 S.E. 907, 913 (1930).Â  
In Peden, Furman University leased its baseball field 
  to the Greenville Baseball Association.Â  Frequently, baseballs were batted over 
  the fence surrounding the ball field onto other landownersâ€™ property.Â  When 
  a neighboring landowner sued, the University claimed it had no control over 
  the ball field and, therefore, could not be held liable for any nuisance caused 
  by its use.Â  Id.Â  The supreme court found the University had â€œcomplete 
  controlâ€ of the property under terms of the lease, and concluded the University 
  could be held liable.Â  Id.Â  Furthermore, the court stated, â€œIn order 
  to charge the landlord, the nuisance must necessarily result from the ordinary 
  use of the premises by the tenant, or for the purpose for which they were let 
  . . . .â€ Id.Â  
International Paper argues it cannot be liable for a nuisance 
  arising from its tenantsâ€™ use of the land in light of recent South Carolina 
  decisions that hold landlords are not liable for the actions of dogs belonging 
  to their tenants, even in cases where the landlord knew of the danger of a foreseeable 
  harm.Â  See Mitchell v. Bazzle, 304 S.C. 402, 404 S.E.2d 910 (Ct. 
  App. 1991).Â  In Mitchell, this court found that even though the landlord 
  knew of the dogâ€™s viciousness, had adequate time to terminate the tenantâ€™s lease, 
  and failed to terminate the tenantâ€™s lease, the landlord was not liable for 
  the acts of the tenantâ€™s dog over, which the landlord had no control.Â  Id., 
  at 405, 404 S.E.2d at 911-12. Also, in Fair v. United States, 334 S.C. 
  321, 513 S.E.2d 616 (1999), the supreme court held a landlord was not liable 
  to a tenantâ€™s invitee for harm caused by the tenantâ€™s dog.Â  International Paper 
  argues that if a landowner cannot be held liable for damages based on the facts 
  in these cases, it would be inappropriate to hold the landowner responsible 
  for the actions of its tenantsâ€™ dogs in the instant action.Â  
Because Mitchell and Fair were actions in tort 
  based on negligence and premises liability, we find these cases are inapplicable.Â  
  FOC Lawsheâ€™s cause of action is based on nuisance.Â  Negligence is not an element 
  of nuisance, and an action for nuisance may lie even though there has been no 
  negligence on the part of the landlord.Â  See Peden, 155 S.C. at 
  17-18, 151 S.E. 912 (stating a landlord can be found liable for a nuisance even 
  though he may have exercised reasonable care).Â  Moreover, the mere fact that 
  dogs are the relevant subjects of the alleged nuisance does not in itself place 
  the action in any particular category of cases.Â  We see no rationale for distinguishing 
  a nuisance caused by dogs from a nuisance caused by baseballs where both enter 
  upon a neighborâ€™s land disrupting the use and enjoyment of the property. Accordingly, 
  Peden is controlling.Â  Under Peden, the appropriate analysis is 
  whether International Paper had complete control over the land and whether the 
  alleged nuisance necessarily results from the ordinary use of the lands by International 
  Paperâ€™s tenants or for the purpose for which the lands were let.Â  155 S.C. at 
  19, 151 S.E. at 913.Â  Applying Peden, we find FOC Lawshe alleged sufficient 
  facts to state a cause of action against International Paper.
In its complaint, 
  FOC Lawshe alleges that despite the leases to the hunt clubs, International 
  Paper reserved the right to and does control the premises and the activities 
  on the land.Â  The complaint alleges that International Paper allows the use 
  of its lands for the type of deer hunting which uses dogs to drive the deer.Â  
  Moreover, the complaint alleges the dogs used by the hunt clubs will continue 
  to trespass onto FOC Lawsheâ€™s lands.Â  FOC Lawshe alleges this continuing trespass 
  prevents it using its property for the purpose for which it was purchased. 
In reviewing a 
  motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), we look only to the pleadings to 
  determine whether sufficient facts are alleged to establish a cause of action.Â  
  See Brown, 291 S.C. at 366, 353 S.E.2d at 698.Â  In viewing the 
  face of the complaint, we find the allegation that International Paper retained 
  control over the property and activities thereon sufficiently satisfies the 
  control element of Peden.Â  155 S.C. at 19, 151 S.E. at 913.Â  Moreover, 
  the allegation that International Paper permits the use of its lands for the 
  type of deer hunting utilizing dogs and that the dogs will continue to enter 
  onto FOC Lawsheâ€™s land satisfies the requirement that the nuisance must necessarily 
  result from the ordinary use of the premises by the tenant, or for the purpose 
  for which they were let.Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial judge was 
  correct in denying International Paperâ€™s motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 
  12(b)(6).
B.Â  Temporary Injunction
FOC Lawshe asserts 
  the trial court erred in denying its motion for a temporary injunction prohibiting 
  International Paper from allowing the use of dogs for hunting on its land.Â  
  We disagree.
A plaintiff's entitlement 
  to an injunction requires the complaint to allege facts sufficient to constitute 
  a cause of action for an injunction while establishing that an injunction is 
  reasonably necessary to protect the legal rights of the plaintiff during the 
  litigation.Â  Transcontâ€™l Gas Pipe Line Corp. v. Porter, 252 S.C. 478, 
  480-81, 167 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1969).Â  Generally, to obtain an injunction, a party 
  must demonstrate irreparable harm, a likelihood of success on the merits, and 
  an inadequate remedy at law.Â  Roach v. Combined Util. Commâ€™n, 290 S.C. 
  437, 442, 351 S.E.2d 168, 170 (Ct. App. 1986).
While the harm 
  caused by the dogs invading FOC Lawsheâ€™s property is likely to continue, we 
  believe the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in refusing to grant the 
  temporary injunction.Â  A requisite level of control must be shown in order to 
  find an owner liable for the actions of a lessee who causes a nuisance to an 
  adjoining property owner.Â Â  Peden, 155 S.C at 19, 151 S.E. at 912.Â  In 
  Peden, the lease provided that the landowner maintained control of the 
  maintenance of the baseball park.Â  Moreover, the court found the lease gave 
  the landowner control over the height of the fence, and the landowner could 
  have taken several steps to prevent baseballs from traveling into the neighboring 
  property.Â  Id.Â  
Looking beyond the face of the complaint, we find conflicting 
  evidence in the record concerning whether International Paper maintained complete 
  control over the activities taking place on its lands.Â  FOC Lawshe alleges that 
  International Paper maintained control over its lands and the activities thereon.Â  
  In support of this allegation, the record indicates that International Paper 
  created buffer zones between its lands and FOC Lawsheâ€™s lands in an attempt 
  to limit the trespassing by the dogs.Â  However, FOC Lawsheâ€™s own affidavits, 
  as well as one submitted by International Paper, suggest International Paper 
  may not have control over its lesseesâ€™ hunting activities.Â  The affidavit by 
  Steven Fisher, president of FOC Lawshe, states: 

I am informed and believe that [International Paper] has 
  agreed with the Sand Hill Hunting Club and the Pine Island Hunting Club to allow 
  each club to have the right to hunt deer on certain areas, assigned to each 
  club, on the lands owned by it.Â  Except for the permitted hunting thereon, 
  I am informed and believe that [International Paper] retains the right to and 
  does control the premises and activities thereon.

(emphasis added).Â  
Peden requires a 
  finding of complete control before the landlord may be held liable.Â  At this 
  point in the action, the issue of complete control remains unadjudicated.Â  See 
  County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 670, 560 S.E.2d 902, 905 
  (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Whether International Paper retained complete control over 
  its lands is a question of fact, and it is for the finder of fact to weigh the 
  conflicting evidence in the record.Â  The fact finder must first decide whether 
  International Paper retained complete control before the court can justify imposing 
  an injunction prohibiting the use of hunting dogs on International Paperâ€™s property.Â  
  Because the issue of control has not been adjudicated, no injunction is needed, 
  at this time, to preserve the status quo.Â  Id. at 671, 560 S.E.2d at 
  906 (finding the operation of an alleged sexually oriented business could not 
  be enjoined without first adjudicating whether the business had actually violated 
  an ordinance because to do so would not preserve the partiesâ€™ positions pending 
  a decision on the merits).Â  Because there is conflicting evidence in the record, 
  the trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying FOC Lawsheâ€™s motion 
  for a temporary injunction.Â  Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 601, 553 S.E.2d at 
  121. 
CONCLUSION
We find the trial 
  judge correctly denied International Paperâ€™s motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 
  12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  The complaint alleges facts sufficient to support a cause 
  of action in nuisance.Â  Additionally, we find the trial judge did not abuse 
  his discretion in denying FOC Lawsheâ€™s motion for a temporary injunction.Â  Accordingly, 
  the decisions of the trial judge are 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and HOWARD, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] We note the denial of a motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6) 
    is generally not immediately appealable.Â  However, an order that is not directly 
    appealable can be considered if there is an appealable issue before the court.Â  
    See Cox v. Woodman of World Ins. Co., 347 S.C. 460, 469, 556 
    S.E.2d 397, 402 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Â

THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
David Nexsen, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Richard B. Haddock, Aubrey 
        E. Judy, James G. Lifrage, Marion Driggers, Larry Poston, Kenneth E.
McClary, 
        Jerry L. Weaver, Billy D. Weaver, Glen Weaver and Gerald Weaver, 
Of whom,Â  James G. Lifrage 
        and Marion Driggers are, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal 
  From Williamsburg County
Â Thomas 
  W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion 
  No. 3581
Heard 
  November 5, 2002 â€“ Filed December 19, 2002Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael G. Nettles, of Lake City; 
  for Appellants.
Jeffrey L. Payne, 
  James D. Smith, Jr., of Florence; for Respondent.
      
    
  


CURETON, 
  J.: David Nexsen brought this action seeking a declaration that the sublease 
  between Kenneth E. McClary, James G. Lifrage and Marion Driggers is a nullity 
  pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-35-60 (1976, as amended). The trial judge found 
  the sublease to be invalid.Â  Lifrage and Driggers appeal.Â  We affirm.
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In 1996, David Nexsen purchased a tract of land on the Black River in Williamsburg 
  County, South Carolina. At the time the property was purchased, the tract had 
  been divided into three lots, with each lot being subject to a lease.Â Â  Kenneth 
  E. McClary was a tenant on lot 2 and a party to one of the leases.Â  McClaryâ€™s 
  lease allowed for the use and occupancy of the premises as the tenant â€œdesired.â€ 
  The terms of the lease did not prohibit the subleasing of the property. Â 
In July, 
  2000, McClary entered into a sublease with James G. Lifrage and Marion Driggers 
  (Appellants).Â  This lease was recorded in the Office of the Clerk of Court for 
  Williamsburg County. Neither McClary, nor Appellants, asked Nexsenâ€™s permission 
  prior to entering into the sublease.Â  
Nexsen brought 
  this action seeking to have the lease between McClary and Appellants declared 
  a nullity.Â  Following a hearing on both partiesâ€™ motions for summary judgment, 
  the trial judge held that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-35-60 prohibits the sublease of 
  property without the written consent of the landlord, and as a result, the sublease 
  between the Appellants and McClary was invalid.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants 
  aver the trial court erred in finding that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-35-60 prohibits 
  the sublease of property without the written consent of the landlord under the 
  facts of this case.Â  Appellants contend that the terms of the lease agreement 
  control the issue of whether McClary was able to sublease the property.Â  Appellants 
  argue that because the lease contains language to the effect that the tenant 
  may use the property â€œas desiredâ€, and because the original owner testified 
  he had no intention of limiting McClaryâ€™s ability to sublease the property, 
  that under the terms of the lease, McClary had the right to sublease the property. 
  
When Nexsen purchased 
  the tract of land in question, the property continued to be burdened with the 
  lease entered into between McClary and the previous owner of the tract.Â Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-35-50 (1976): 

 When real estate is 
  sold while under lease, the relationship of landlord and tenant is created ipso 
  facto as between the purchaser and the tenant as if the purchaser had been the 
  landlord in the first instance and the purchaser shall be entitled to all the 
  benefits and rights under such lease as if he had been the lessor from the date 
  of the purchase.

Nexsen contends, however, 
  that because the lease is silent as to whether or not the property may beÂ  subleased, 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-35-60 controls.Â  The statute states:

 A sublease by a tenant 
  without written consent of the landlord is a nullity insofar as the rights of 
  the landlord are concerned, except that rent collected by a tenant from a subtenant 
  shall be deemed to be held in trust by the tenant for the benefit of the landlord 
  until the payment of the landlordâ€™s claim for rent.Â  But when the premises have 
  been sublet the sublessor, as between himself and the subtenant or sublessee, 
  shall be deemed the landlord and the sublessee the tenant under him . . .Â Â  
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-35-60 
  (1976).Â Â  Nexsen argues Â§ 27-35-60 prohibits McClary from subleasing the property. 
  
â€œIn reviewing 
  the grant of a summary judgment motion, we apply the same standard which governs 
  the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP. Summary judgment is proper when there 
  is no genuine issue as to any material fact and . . .Â  the moving party is entitled 
  to judgment as a matter of law.â€ Baughman v. American Tel. and Tel. Co., 
  306 S.C. 101, 114-15, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991) (citations omitted). â€œWhen 
  an appeal involves stipulated or undisputed facts, an appellate court is free 
  to review whether the trial court properly applied the law to those facts.â€ 
  WDW Prop. v. City of Sumter, 342 S.C. 6, 10, 535 S.E.2d 631, 632 (2000). 
  
â€œThe 
  cardinal rule of statutory construction is that we are to ascertain and effectuate 
  the actual intent of the legislature.â€Â  Burns v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. 
  Co., 297 S.C. 520, 522, 377 S.E.2d 569, 570 (1989).Â  â€œ[W]ords used therein 
  must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced 
  construction to limit or expand its operation.â€Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. 
  v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â Â  â€œThe language 
  must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords 
  with its general purpose.â€Â  Id.
Examining 
  the terms of the lease, we find the language in the lease agreement that the 
  tenant shall â€œuse and occupy the premises as desired, including the construction 
  of a dwelling, etc., thereonâ€ is not sufficient to convey to McClary the right 
  to sublease the property.Â  Therefore, applying the plain meaning of S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 27-35-60 to the facts and circumstances of this case, we find that absent 
  Nexsenâ€™s written consent, the sublease between McClary and Appellants is a nullity. 
  See Dobyns v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Parks, Recreation and Tourisim, 252 
  S.C. 97, 103, 480 S.E.2d 81, 84 (1997) (where our supreme court refused to adopt 
  a reasonableness requirement into a lease that permitted subleasing â€œupon the 
  consent of the leasorâ€).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the judgment of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, J., concur.
